facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 481 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 481 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 447 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order, dated April 30, 1965, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 447 of 1965.

facts.text: Last general election of the members of the Bhusaval Borough Municipality was held in the year 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The facts lie in a small compass. The last general election of the, members of the Bhusaval Borough Municipality was held under the provisions of the Act in the year 1960.

facts.text: First general meeting of the Municipality was held on February 18, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first general meeting thereafter was held on February 18, 1961.

facts.text: Under s. 25 of the Act, in the normal course the life of the Municipality would have expired on February 17, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of s. 25 of the Act. in the normal course the life of the Municipality would have expired on February 17, 1965

facts.text: Under s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act the term of the Councillors of the Municipality was extended to and inclusive of December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: but, under s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act the term of the Councillors of the Municipality was, by fiction, extended to and inclusive of December 31, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant was elected the President of the Municipality on July 18, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1964, the appellant was elected the President of the Municipality

facts.text: On July 18, 1964, the Municipality passed a resolution that the term of the office of the President shall be the residue of the term of office of the Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day the Municipality passed a resolution to the effect that the term of the office of the President shall be the residue of the term of office of the Municipality.

facts.text: Collector of Jalgaon issued a notice on March 2, 1965, calling for a meeting of the Municipality on March 15, 1965, for electing a new President.

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the term of the President expired on February 17, 1965, the Collector of Jalgaon issued a notice on March 2, 1965, calling for a meeting of the Municipality on March 15, 1965, for electing a new President.

facts.text: Appellant filed an application under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court of Maharashtra against the notice issued by the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed an application under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court of Maharashtra for the issue of an appropriate order setting aside the notice issued by the Collector.

facts.text: Appellant contended in High Court that his term as President extended to December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: There the appellant contended that, as the term of office of the Municipality had been extended by the Maharashtra Act up to December 31, 1965, he was entitled to continue in office as President till that date.

facts.text: Division Bench of Bombay High Court rejected appellant's contention and dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court rejected that contention and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the appeal.

facts.text: Municipality passed a resolution recommending extension of its term beyond 4 years on or about July 18, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, on or about July 18, 1964, when the term of the President of the Municipality was extended, the Municipality passed a resolution recommending that the term of the Municipality be extended beyond 4 years.

facts.text: Government appointed a Committee in July 1963 for unification of municipal acts.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1963, Government appointed a Committee for the purpose of considering the question of unification of the four Municipal Acts which are at present in force in the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is not Correct and the same is set aside.

facts.text: Writ issued prohibiting Collector from holding election of President till December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality of the Bhusaval Borough till December 31, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant argued that he gets extended term under second proviso to s.19 or Maharashtra Act amends s.25.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Agarwala, learned counsel for the appellant, contended that the appellant would get the extended term provided in the Maharashtra Act, because in effect it was an extension under the Act within the meaning of the second proviso to s. 19 of the Act

facts.text: Respondent argued second proviso s.19 has no application as extension not under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, on the other hand, argued that the second proviso to s. 19 of the Act had no application, for it dealt only with an extension by notification or otherwise under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: Resolution passed previous to election of President, construed on circumstances at that time.

anchor.surface_text: the scope of the resolution passed by the Municipality should be construed on the basis of the circumstances existing at the time the resolution was passed, i.e., previous to the election of the President

facts.text: Term of Councillors under s.25 is 4 years, extensible to 5 years by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 25 of the Act the term of the Councillors of the Municipality is 4 years. It may be extended by the State Government to a term not exceeding in the aggregate five years.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao J.

facts.text: Maharashtra Act s.3 extends term of Councillors whose term expires before Dec 31, 1965 to that date.

anchor.surface_text: Section 19 of the Act Save as otherwise provided in this Act a president or vice-president, shall hold his office for such term, not less than one year or not less than the residue of the term of office of the municipality, whichever is less and not exceeding four years, as the municipality shall, previous to the election of the president or vicepresident determine, or until the expiry within the said term of his term of office, as councillor, but shall be eligible for reelection Provided that Provided further that where the term of office of a municipality Is extended under this Act to a term not exceeding in the aggregate five years the president and vice-president holding offices immediately before the date with effect from which such term is extended shall continue to hold their respective offices until the date on which the term so extended expires.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Maharashtra Act Postponement of municipal elections.-Notwithstanding anything in any Act by or under which any municipality is constituted or established,-  a   b  the term or extended term of office, of the Councillors or members of a municipality, who were in office on the date of the commencement of the Ordinance  and whose term or extended term will expire before the 31st day of December 1965 , shall be deemed to be extended to and inclusive of the 31st day of December 1965.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order of High Court not correct

arguments.claim: Municipality's resolution fixing President's term as residue of Municipality's term includes extended term by Maharashtra Act

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution. Under s. 19 of the Act, the Municipality can fix the term of office of the President between one and four years, except when the residue of the term of the Municipality is less than one year. But the second proviso to s. 19 also contemplates the extension of the term of office of the Municipality under the provisions of the Act. It is, therefore, not possible to predicate that at the time the resolution was passed the Municipality could not have contemplated a situation when the term of the Municipality would be extended under the provisions of the Act. With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time. If that was their intention they would have prescribed a definite date on which the term of the President would expire. That apart, there is sufficient material on the record which indicates that the councillors designedly used the word residue instead of fixing a precise date. It appears that it was in the contemplation of the councillors at the time of the election of the President that there was a possibility of the term of the Municipality being extended. ... the intention appears to be that the term of the President should synchronize with the life of the Municipality existing or extended, as the case may be.

arguments.claim: Councillors contemplated extension of Municipality term under Act provisions when passing resolution

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 19 of the Act, the Municipality can fix the term of office of the President between one and four years, except when the residue of the term of the Municipality is less than one year. But the second proviso to s. 19 also contemplates the extension of the term of office of the Municipality under the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Use of elastic 'residue' rather than definite date shows intention for term to synchronize with possibly extended Municipality life

anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge of such a possible extension, when the members used the elastic expression residue, it is not reasonable to attribute to them the intention that they meant only the residue of the term available to them at that time. If that was their intention they would have prescribed a definite date on which the term of the President would expire.

arguments.claim: Background circumstances including 1963 committee, statement of objects, and Municipality's own resolution recommending extension show expectation of term extension

anchor.surface_text: In the Statement of Objects underlying the issuance of the Ordinance which culminated in the Maharashtra Act, it was observed as follows In July, 1963, Government appointed a Committee for the purpose of considering the question of unification of the four Municipal Acts which are at present in force in the State. ... Indeed, on or about July 18, 1964, when the term of the President of the Municipality was extended, the Municipality passed a resolution recommending that the term of the Municipality be extended beyond 4 years. It is, therefore, clear that on the basis of statutory and other circumstances obtaining at the time the extension was made, the councillors clearly expected that the term of the Municipality would be or could be extended

holdings.text: The second proviso to s. 19 of the Act is not attracted to the instant case because there was no order or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors.

anchor.surface_text: If that be the legal effect of s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act, the second proviso is not attracted to the instant case, as there was noorder or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors fixed under s. 25 of the Act. Therefore for the present purpose we leave out of consideration the second proviso to s. 19 and approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extension by Maharashtra Act is not 'under this Act' as required by second proviso; no notification under s.25 issued.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the Maharashtra Act creates a legal fiction extending the term of councillors prescribed under s.25 of the Act (and any extended term) to December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The impact of s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act on the provisions of the Act is that it not only extends the term prescribed under s. 25 of the Act but also the term extended under s. 25 or under any other section of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 uses 'deemed to be extended' notwithstanding any other Act, covering terms under s.25 directly and extended ones.

holdings.text: The expression 'the residue of the term of office of the Municipality' in the resolution dated July 18, 1964 includes the extended term under the Maharashtra Act up to December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The intention of the Municipality can be gathered only from the circumstances, statutory or otherwise existing at the time when the resolution was passed and on the express terms of the said resolution. Under s. 19 of the Act, the Municipality can fix the term of office of the President between one and four years, except when the residue of the term of the Municipality is less than one year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention from statutory context (s.19 contemplates extensions), elastic 'residue' vs fixed date, background (committee, own resolution recommending extension) shows synchronization with existing or extended life.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court is not correct and the same is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, the order of the High Court is not Correct and the same is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on construction of resolution including extended term.

holdings.text: A writ will issue prohibiting the Collector from holding the election of the President of the Municipality till December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: If that be the legal effect of s. 3 of the Maharashtra Act, the second proviso is not attracted to the instant case, as there was noorder or notification issued under s. 25 or any other relevant section of the Act extending the term of the councillors fixed under s. 25 of the Act. Therefore for the present purpose we leave out of consideration the second proviso to s. 19 and approach the problem on the basis of the fiction that the term of the councillors prescribed under s. 25 of the Act was extended up to December 31, 1965.
